newsitem.title: FRANCE: French justice minister unveils reform plans.
newsitem.headline: French justice minister unveils reform plans.

text.p: France's new Justice Minister Elisabeth Guigou has said she will push through bills to stiffen punishment of sex crimes and reform citizenship rules.

In an interview with the daily Le Figaro to be published on Tuesday, Guigou, a Socialist who took office this month, indicated the two bills would be debated in the National Assembly's next session in the autumn.
Prime Minister Lionel Jospin has said he wants to restore the tradition of automatically granting citizenship to anyone born on French soil, which was dented by the previous conservative government.

The conservatives, in an effort to curb immigration, pushed through a law making it necessary for French-born children of foreign parents to formally request citizenship when they reach the age of 18.
Guigou said she intended to revive a bill to stiffen the punishment for sex crimes and dissemination of pornography.
The bill's passage through parliament was interrupted last April when conservative President Jacques Chirac called an early election, which swept the left into power.
The new legislation would force sex offenders to undergo treatment with the aim of preventing recidivism, and deprive them of routine prison sentence reductions.
Guigou said she had received a report requested by Chirac on a wider reform to guarantee judicial independence among other things.
She said she would make proposals after studying the report drafted by a a 21-member bipartisan commission headed by Supreme Court president Pierre Truche.

Guigou reiterated Jospin's commitments that the government would keep hands off all judicial probes into political sleaze, following accusations that the previous government had tried to hamper some investigations.
She appeared to bury plans by her conservative predecessor Jacques Toubon to stiffen anti-racist legislation.
"I do not intend to legislate...without being sure that one cannot do better by firmly applying existing laws," she said.

Toubon had planned to reform the existing law which punishes racist comments only when they targeted a specific group, and had proved too vague to allow prosecution of far-right National Front leader Jean-Marie Le Pen for espousing racial inequality.
